docs.snippet: The National College Players Association, the group that organized the protest, said 28 players from three universities — Northwestern, Georgia and Georgia Tech — participated....
docs.lead_paragraph: The National College Players Association, the group that organized the protest, said 28 players from three universities — Northwestern, Georgia and Georgia Tech — participated.
docs.abstract: Some 28 college football players participate in simple protest organized by the National College Players Assn, adding their voices to growing chorus calling for NCAA reform; organization hopes to spread involvement in protest, which consists of wearing letters APU, for All Players United, on uniforms.

headline.main: With Simple Protest, Players Join Push for N.C.A.A. Reform
headline.print_headline: With Simple Protest, Players Join Push for N.C.A.A. Reform

docs.snippet: Awards can be powerful motivators, but nonstop recognition does not inspire children to succeed. Instead, it can cause them to underachieve....
docs.lead_paragraph: Awards can be powerful motivators, but nonstop recognition does not inspire children to succeed. Instead, it can cause them to underachieve.
docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by author Ashley Merryman warns that awards and prizes given to children on an almost constant basis, sometimes merely for participation, do not inspire them to succeed, and instead cause them to underachieve; argues that losing is a valuable lesson, and it is up to parents to help them overcome setbacks and let them see that progress over time is more important that a particular win or loss.
